docs.lead_paragraph: The discovery of a statistical link between coffee drinking and pancreatic cancer, reported last week, foreshadows far more attention to the health effects of this stimulant used by at least 100 million Americans. In the past there has been little evidence to link coffee with ill effects on health, but last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, scientists at Harvard's School of Public Health reported that coffee drinkers had a substantially heightened chance of developing cancer when compared with people who did not drink coffee. The statistical link is firm, but it does not necessarily prove cause and effect. It does raise scientists' feelings that more research is needed.
